Message.Msg: I use the max pain website, and the numbers are different (there are currently 4,080 put contacts OI at $265 for Fri . there are 56k total put contract OI at all prices). Bottom line ... Max pain remains at $280, and the extra losses with the stock at $305 vs. $280 is $59M. That may not be enough to push the stock down much. Especially with the Lazrd capital target increase to $340 from $310 this morning.

Message.Title: SEARS TO BECOME THIRD PARTY SELLLERS-MAKE COMMISSION
Message.Msg: Sears used to be king of catalogues. What do you think about Sears third party selling? I like idea what amazon is doing third party sellers, great innovation by Jeff Bezos. Bread and Butter of Amazon business. Electronics products the number one selling item. If Sears developed a platform for e-commerce third party sellers and also sell there own products this would reinvent there business. The convenience of shopping from your home. Look at all small businesses across America that need to use a brand name to sell products. Any opinions welcomed.

Topic.Title: I think , in all seriousness, ther's a big thing shorts are missing, as Bernanke, Japan, and Europe print money,

Message.Msg: thinngs can't fall in prices when the Fed is printing, right or wrong from here, and AMZN appears to always get the most benefit of it. I think their printing is being directed to companies they hope will build out infrastructure that lessons costs ahead. That's why analyzing AMZN on earnings today, is a big mistake still. As the Fed blows out the balance sheet, AMZN keeps going up, lately more agreesively and relentlessly. P/E analysis just doesn't work and way too superficial. Which makes the whole process of Bernanke's actions getting Jeff Bezos going toward being the richest man ever at this rate. Someday, maybe earnings will be more scrutinized, just hard to know when. That's just my view. Hopefully , to not make it a farce, Bezos doesn't become the richest before the company starts pulling in money to retained earnings somewhere ahead. Then, perhaps Bernanke has gone too far in playing favorites.

Topic.Title: I have yet to hear Nasdaq or Skiidady or other bulls explain why Internet Groceries is a Good Idea

Message.Msg: Amazon has no other places to grow its revenue, try to keep its stock at bubble high. It has to find a way to grow its revenue even though it's a bad idea, and very bad idea. Considering who would buy milk, breads, vegetable, fruits and meat online without physical seeing it. When they are delivered to your door. They are already on the track for several hours possible.

Topic.Title: I have yet to hear Nasdaq or Skiidady or other bulls explain why Internet Groceries is a Good Idea

Message.Msg: Groceries have been test marketed so the results must have been promising to roll out the program. In case you haven't noticed Amazon is not price competitive on most grocery items so there is some margin there. My guess is that Amazon is targeting two groups. The first is young urban professionals whose time is valuable. They're willing to pay more for groceries for the convenience. The second group is restaurants. When I was in Seattle last year I saw a large Ammie truck down by the piers delivering to restaurants. There's margin in wholesaling better quality food. I suspect Amazon has found a way to reduce delivery costs by using their own trucks and vans. Am I confident the Amazon grocery program is going to be successful? Of course not. Bezos uses his company as a giant test tube. Some experiments work while others don't. I do think this program has a better than 50-50 chance of making it. Why do you think it's "the nuttiest idea ever"?

Message.Msg: Amazon has many ways to grow their revenue. They've concentrated on tech and entertainment products while ignoring others. Yes they have products for the home but they're poorly presented and merchandised. The list of under-served product categories goes on and on. When it comes to profitability Amazon doesn't have a clue. I don't think they know the meaning of inventory CONTROL and return on investment. Amazon is a great company that will continue to be the market leader for decades. But as long as Ammie is Bezos's play toy they will continue to under-perform their potential.

Past bubbles show how reckless it is to do it. So a lot is riding on this policy. And it's getting aggressive here: GOOG toward $1000( at least backed by pretty high earnings run) AMZN over $300, PCLN neainrg $1000, oil at $105, gasoline futures over $3, rates rising, and non-stop Bernanke intervention still there. Seems like same easy money as the past, but this time all based on suppressing rates for so low with top price buying of US bonds. When you buy those Treasuries as close to 0 % as the Fed has along the curve of maturity, your paying top dollar to get those conditons. So rates might hold the key: Fed chose not to clean the system but to relever with even more aggressive paper deluge.

Topic.Title: techstrategy are u here brother

Topic.Title: techstrategy are u here brother

Message.Msg: Not a scam? We had the Segway craze, shoes craze, diaper craze, e-book/e-reader craze, tablet craze, cloud craze, grocery delivery craze...and still no meaningful profit after 16 yrs. Management hops on the latest flavor of the month, then promises great earning that will someday materialize. It's the same story over and over again...for almost twenty years.

Topic.Title: techstrategy are u here brother

Message.Msg: It's rather amazing what the cult will do to make him money -- in our reflexive scam markets, all that matters is perception and he has such a cult following that it changes perception. He parachuted in on GMCR and said NOTHING that wasn't obvious (as I posted virtually his entire short thesis on the YMB in the months before him...). Not much different for CMG. Nonetheless, I do not begrudge him success. I just despise the malinvestment that these float jam scams engender... I don't think he'll need to parachute in this time since we're heading for a crisis that will make everything before it look tame... "Fed is the Problem" Article on ZH by Rajan makes the point that I've been making for the past 5 years "There are two ways these calculations can go wrong. First, financial risk taking may stay just that, without translating into real investment. For instance, the price of junk debt or homes may be bid up unduly, increasing the risk of a crash, without new capital goods being bought or homes being built." Bottom line is that the casino known as the stock/bond market creates no value, yet Fin sector profits have gone from ~1.5% of GDP to over 5% of GDP in about 20 years. When value creation approximates zero and value capture is 5% over GDP, it can only lead to destabilizing outcomes over time...

Topic.Title: techstrategy are u here brother

Message.Msg: I wish I had more time to post, but I'm working on several very cool companies and not sleeping much these days as it is... Frankly, none of my fundamental analysis has changed (although gas prices increasing will exacerbate the inherent flaws in Amazon's "middling" strategy), so there's no real reason for me to post any more. Those who think this will keep climbing, you just got a warning sign from TSLA which cratered AFTER being added to the Nas100. The entire game is to move against fundamentals and dump crap into passive ETFs over time (aided by rebalancing and QE hype). There is NO fundamental support for this stock. It isn't an inflation or hyperinflation hedge (what would happen to consumer purchasing power or fuel prices in said environment?). It is a trading scam and nothing more...
